body: @dubeejw could put some 👀 on this when you have a chance
@csantanapr, @rabbah, needs review.

A few key steps to get this ball rolling:
- [ ] a [`hello.rb` script](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tests/dat/actions) that takes in a dict (hash ?) and returns a modified dict
- [ ] a [Dockerfile](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/core) that builds a reasonable Ruby version
- [ ] a related [build.gradle](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/core/pythonAction/build.gradle) to drive the docker build

If we could get those three things done, we could evaluate the feasibility of this request.

Where do we want to go with this one?

Now that [tools/travis/flake8.sh](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/travis/flake8.sh) is run against every pull request, we get [pages and pages of style errors](https://travis-ci.org/openwhisk/openwhisk/builds/213435574#L339) on every Travis build.  This is similar to what you would get locally on each commit if you do [`flake8 --install-hook git`](http://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/using-hooks.html) on your workstation.

So now that we have access to the data, do we really want to fix these issues or do we just close this issue?
FYI @rabbah

Other considerations:
- The web action response context (i.e. the action extension - .http, .json, etc) would also need to be specified
- Response parsing.  Web action responses can be somewhat free form, so beyond the response status code, any other internal error structure will likely be beyond the CLI's capability.  The `-r` option does not apply to web-actions.
- Other `wsk action invoke` options.  web-actions are blocking by nature, so the `-b` option does not apply to web action invocation.
@csantanapr, this relates to the discussion we about CLI gaps related to web actions.
Yep bringing @bjustin-ibm into the loop as he has a use case to use web actions as trigger feed actions

As I stated before - we have so little python code that we should not obsess over it. It's functional, it's tested. If there's no interest in fixing the style error from others, I would disable the pages and pages of style errors and live with it.
Tell me again why you want to invoke the action as a web action instead of a normal action? (A web action may be invoked with `wsk action invoke` of course.)
Would `wsk action invoke --web` be the equivalent of doing a `curl`? As noted by @mdeuser there are enough differences to not treat this as part of "invoke" commands.

> Tell me again why you want to invoke the action as a web action instead of a normal action?

Because I want to invoke a non-shared action but do not have the auth key for it. For the simple `action invoke` this **is** equivalent to using `curl`, but is more useful in the `trigger create` scenario. If we feel that the simple action invoke case is just too silly to support, then I'm ok scoping this down to just the trigger create one.

> Additionally, this flag should apply to the trigger create and trigger delete commands to allow triggers to be created/deleted from feed actions that are web actions.

The web action in this case is serving as an API - it could be curl'ed from the trigger feed action (which is shared)?

Can you elaborate further on the scenario with triggers?
For consistency, if the CLI provides a means for creating a web action, there should also exist the ability to invoke a web action from the CLI even if it is the same as a curl.

> Can you elaborate further on the scenario with triggers?

The scenario is that the feed action needs to be invokable by anyone, but non-shared because it will have bound parameters with sensitive values (super secret credentials). It _could_ be implemented with a shared action that posts to a web action as you suggest, but that is not as simple and performant (two activations for every trigger create) as having a single non-shared web action.

considered changing the _trigger create with a feed_ to instead of accepting an action, to instead accept a url? would that be more general (either created feed by invoking an action or making an http call)?

> For consistency, if the CLI provides a means for creating a web action, there should also exist the ability to invoke a web action from the CLI even if it is the same as a curl.

This could be a different set of sub commands, like the "gw" integration. FWIW do the api-experimental subcommands allow curling the gw endpoints?

> considered changing the trigger create with a feed to instead of accepting an action, to instead accept a url?

Seems like a much heavier mental burden on the user to first find the URL for the feed action they want to invoke. Personally, I don't even like the idea that they have to know the feed action is a web action, but that seems unavoidable.

 It is much simpler to tell them to use (for example) `--web -f messageHubFeed` and have the CLI handle the sticky details of determining the correct URL for them. If we were to require them to pass in the feed action URL, then the documentation for the feed gets much trickier in that we can't just say "use these parameters" and will then have to document how to find the URL for the feed action and pass _that_ as a parameter.

Honestly, I doubt most users that have created a trigger even realize there is an action invocation happening on their behalf - and that is a good thing. They _should_ be able to create triggers without having a detailed understanding of all the work being done for them by the feed.

Also, something just feels icky about allowing them to pass an arbitrary URL to which we are going to POST their feed details. Security risk maybe?

Seems from your explanations that the issue is with the entitlement model - it's not fine grained enough. Sharing a package means the action may be invoked or read where you only want to grant invoke rights. Web actions give you the right entitlement but leak implementation details (i.e., `--web`)? So another question: if we fixed the entitlement to be more fine grained, would it satisfy the requirement in this scenario?

> if we fixed the entitlement to be more fine grained, would it satisfy the requirement in this scenario?

You are totally correct. What I need is the ability to create an action that anyone can invoke without the auth key, but also they cannot see the code or parameter values for this action. If that were possible, ultimately then the CLI would not need to change to support invoking web feed actions.

> that anyone can invoke without the auth key, 

two more thoughts: (sorry for not yet offering answers, i'm trying to clarify the requirements)

1. note that we define that a trigger life cycle event receives an apikey (to fire a trigger on behalf of the user) among other fields
2. invoking an action as a web action changes the cost model for the activation (from caller pays to owner pays)

> note that we define that a trigger life cycle event receives an apikey (to fire a trigger on behalf of the user) among other fields

I'm curious why you chose to point this out. Is this to show that users may not be as blissfully ignorant about feed actions as I suspect, or something else?

> invoking an action as a web action changes the cost model for the activation (from caller pays to owner pays)

Now that is interesting! It makes sense, but is not optimal in the feed action scenario where the caller should be billed.

> I'm curious why you chose to point this out...

In short yes.

The user should be aware they are in fact authorizing triggers to be fired on their behalf, with their apikey. It's arguable this flow should handshake more generally through an OAuth flow where the feed is given a limited access token to fire exactly one trigger, for example. As opposed to the current model where there is just one key.

This is more aligned with the negotiate the feed construction through a web action (API), in that then authentication/authorization are part of the web action flow where the user is more explicitly aware of what's happening, what tokens they are sharing, for what privilege, etc.

On master:

```
rr [master] openwhisk> wsk action invoke echo -p error "a" -br
error: Unable to invoke action 'echo': a (code 0)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
rr [master] openwhisk> wsk action invoke echo -p error true -br
{
    "error": true
}
```

On branch:
```
rr [pr-2045] openwhisk> wsk action invoke echo -p error 1 -br
error: Unable to invoke action 'echo': The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
rr [pr-2045] openwhisk> wsk action invoke echo -p error true -br
error: Unable to invoke action 'echo': The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
rr [pr-2045] openwhisk> wsk action invoke echo -p error "a" -br
{
    "error": "a"
}
```
needs a pg since swift tests dont run in travis.
@rabbah  pg85 in progress
Ready for review.
pg build failure, could be a deployment issue.  Let's rebase on master first and I can try again.
@perryibm ^^
FWIW: action container logs are available via `docker logs` already.

regarding action logs we have hit a performance issue in the past. need to verify if it still exists but I assume it does. `docker logs` is relatively expensive which is why we are not using it to fetch action container logs in the invoker. as a user you can fetch them already using regular docker commands.

core containers are a bit trickier because we need them also in a file because we want to be able to forward them to log processing systems. need to check if both json-docker logs and file logs are possible.

Finally all tests have passed on OSX!!

@rabbah @markusthoemmes kindly review this.

Changes are as follow:

1. Change `mac` environment for `docker for mac`
2. Add new environment `docker-machine` for `mac with docker-machine`
3. Make `HttpUtils` respect proxy.
4. Make `HttpUtils` retry on 503 service unavailable error.
5. Move `AkkaHttpUtils` to the test project.
@domdom82 regarding performance issue, you meant if user tries to get logs while action container is running, it will degrade the performance of system?
For core containers we can just use `tee` to pipe to the file + have it printed on stdout.

I am not sure about log processing systems.

Docker daemon saves logs to files even though container writes logs to stdout.
But the location is little bit tricky.

The logs from the components go to stdout but the docker run pipes that to a file. It's not a tee. The file is mounted in the host where it can be forwarded to elk for example. 

Use "wskadmin syslog get" to dump all logs for controller and invoker0 or "wskadmin syslog get controller" for just controller etc.
@rabbah we could use tee though, to have both the file and stdout (`docker logs`)

To tee the component logs, as markus suggested, we can add a tweak to the docker file I suppose. Not sure it's that useful, is it?

Do you want just to get logs? Or tail -f the logs? We can add that to wskadmin in which case, what does docker logs get you?

Are you thinking about a drain adapter or for local development?

Regarding the idea to send the logs to stdout as well as file, docker daemon stores the logs to files also, there will be duplicate information.

For example, docker daemon stores logs in `LogPath` which is retrieved by `docker inspect`.
Normally that is the container directory in `/var/lib/docker/`

So if we send logs to file and stdout using tools like tee, there will be duplicate information stored in host file system. 

And with regard to this feature request, when I first met OW, I have no idea on `wksadmin` and `/tmp/wsklogs`.
So I just tried `docker logs` to see the logs and no shot.
And I got into the container using `docker exec -it bash` and saw the logs.

There is no specific requirement or thinking.
I just thought that many people who are not yet familiar with OW but familiar with docker, may think like the way I did, and if OW supports this feature, it will make them see the logs more easily.

Fair points. Since in openwhisk we have not included the forwarder, we could send the logs to stdout instead so that as someone starts developing or kicking tires, its familiar to them. And then treat the file redirect and wskadmin as advanced features because really they're more handy than docker logs. 

Or we can better document how-tos for developers. Maybe an FAQ?

My 2c on this: the implicit assumption here is that concurrency implemented through Node's EventLoop is vastly more efficient than concurrency by running containers in parallel. Where "vastly" is large enough to justify looking into the complexity stated above. I think in order to have a meaningful discussion on that we will need a set of shared performance/throughput test scripts (maintained within OW) and results.

Should document in [cli docs](../blob/master/docs/cli.md).
Also need to remove [this](../blob/master/tools/ubuntu-setup/bashprofile.sh#L4).

@mdeuser, thoughts on printing this way? 

We can also update WskError to be a linked list of errors so we do not have to manually concatenate error messages together. This would also make the code more readable.

FYI running perf tests in docker-compose env via ab load test against helloworld.js with #2060 using -a concurrent-max 1000 I get:

```
Percentage of the requests served within a certain time (ms)
  50%    567
  66%    630
  75%    678
  80%    707
  90%    790
  95%    881
  98%   1010
  99%   1124
 100%   1420 (longest request)
```

compare to *without* using the concurrent-max annotation:
```
Percentage of the requests served within a certain time (ms)
  50%   1653
  66%   1819
  75%   1931
  80%   2005
  90%   2330
  95%   2584
  98%   2932
  99%   4060
 100%   7674 (longest request)
```

I'll submit a separate PR to enable rerunning these tests easily in openwhisk-devtools
@dubeejw - during the pluggable-cli research, we may find a "best practice" way of printing out messages to the console.
a suggestion: rerun on master but suppress pause/unpause entirely; from [past results](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1312#issuecomment-251834453) you can get 2x or more from that alone.

Ready for review.

@rabbah, as you mention above this issue is about a rather fundamental design aspect. Do you think it makes sense to discuss this on the mailing list to get broader attention? It would be interesting to understand the history better (why early prototypes implemented this approach and why it was abandoned). Also, I think it would be a good discussion to look at use cases other than public cloud (i.e. private OW deployments). Reason I mention that: that might render moot some of the complexity arguments above.
Really don't know the outcome of such a discussion - but I think it's really worth having it and have it go "on record", because I believe this topic is likely to pop up again.

As part of doing this, consider: adding quiet mode which omits "ok:" and "error:" lines so that raw Json responses are more amenable to post processing.
Alternatively: `--json` or `--raw` to explicitly make the output machine-readable?
merged
@markusthoemmes, @rabbah, a flag like `--raw` would be accomplished through this issue: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/2064.
All of the commands currently receive the HTTP response from each request, but the response body is not accessible as the connection has already been closed.

@dubeejw - changes LGTM.

One comment on a related set of commands that display the nonexistent entity error message incorrectly.  It's the `wsk ENTITY list NAMESPACE` command, and this very well can be a separate issue..  The behavior of the command across the various entities varies.  Most ignore the invalid NAMESPACE and display no error, but the `action list NS` command displays an error with the CLI-configured namespace as the namespace in the error message.

We've merged Swift 3.0.2
Merged 3.0.2

> Does OpenWhisk run the Docker action tests using both Python 2 and Python 3?

The goal of #1903 is that Python 3 would be used for all actions with the exception of Python 2 actions which we would want to deprecate as quickly as possible.  Given that Python 3 has a far more rational/modern approach to unicode, I believe it would be better to focus on making these other languages like Swift work with Python 3 and stop attempting to create Python 2 solutions to this issue.
I 100% agree with the statement that it is better to use feature detection instead of version detection.
